p: There are a growing number and variety of readily available disease-related data sources that may ultimately be integrated into or even replace traditional systems. The Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) relies on data from two primary national influenza surveillance systems: (1) the U.S. World Health Organization (WHO) and National Respiratory and Enteric Virus Surveillance System (NREVSS) collaborating laboratories (henceforth, WHO US) and (2) the US Outpatient Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet). Recently, Meaningful Use [ 12], a CDC led effort, is advancing the expansion of syndromic surveillance systems such as ESSENCE to address a broader set of infectious disease surveillance objectives [ 13â€“ 15].
